sub_topic: Finding the derivative of a trigonometric function
message_1: Find the derivative of the function y = sin(x) + 3cos(x) when x = π/2.
message_2:
To find the derivative of the function y = sin(x) + 3cos(x), we will differentiate each term with respect to x.

The derivative of sin(x) with respect to x is cos(x), and the derivative of 3cos(x) with respect to x is -3sin(x). So the derivative of y with respect to x is:

dy/dx = cos(x) - 3sin(x)

Now, we will evaluate the derivative at x = π/2:

dy/dx = cos(π/2) - 3sin(π/2)

cos(π/2) = 0 and sin(π/2) = 1, so:

dy/dx = 0 - 3(1) = -3

Therefore, the derivative of the function y = sin(x) + 3cos(x) when x = π/2 is -3.
